important_phrase: Crop conditions were described as generally favorable for cotton,   soybeans, and peanuts in Alabama, Georgia, and Mississippi
Reports from real estate contacts indicated that home   sales continued to improve in most areas, although the pace of the improvement   slowed somewhat in September
District businesses noted that the   pace of layoffs slowed in September, but there continued to be concerns over   hiring as few contacts reported any plans to increase payrolls
Real estate contacts mentioned that   homebuyers had difficulty securing financing for non-conforming mortgages
Overall, transportation activity remained weak, with rail shipments of   automobiles being one of the few areas showing improvement
Demand for low- to mid-priced homes remained relatively   strong, supported by the first-time home buyer tax credit and increased interest   by investors
Used-car sales held relatively steady over the month
Business activity remains slow in the First District, notwithstanding some   signs of improvement
By contrast, several contacts cite   slower-than-anticipated demand in the third quarter
Leasing velocity remains slow, but increased modestly   from the summer as tenants sought to upgrade space at bargain prices
Tourism activity in Boston is weak, although the rate of decline has slowed
Early reports indicated lower than   expected yields for corn and some issues with quality
Credit conditions, while still tight, also further improved
Price pressures were mixed in September   and early October
Credit conditions, while still tight,   further improved in September and early October
The decline in business spending slowed   in September and early October, and the outlook for future spending improved
Commercial construction was particularly weak
Retail sales excluding autos decreased at a slower   rate than during the previous reporting period
Little change in oil and gas output was   reported, while drilling activity was steady or slowly declining
New home sales showed a modest improvement, while commercial and   industrial construction continued at a slow pace
Interest rates and spreads were steady to increasing
Looking forward, a majority of our contacts expect   slight incremental improvements in volume
Inquiries are coming in at a   much slower pace, while backlogs are down substantially for nearly all builders
Vehicle inventories remain low
Although short-term   moisture conditions have improved, long-term deficits persist in south and   central Texas
Economic conditions were little changed in the Eleventh District in September   and early October, but there continued to be scattered signs of improvement
Price pressures remain subdued across industries
Respondents remain very cautious in   their outlooks, and some noted concern about upcoming changes in the regulatory   environment
Contacts in accounting services reported steady, moderate   demand
However, outlooks   for any significant upturn remain uncertain
Retail demand was largely unchanged from the   last report, and sales in Texas continued to track the national average
Overall drilling   activity improved slightly over the previous month, mainly among crude oil   producers, and activity was expected to remain stable
The Tenth District economy expanded slightly in September and early October
Consumer prices generally decreased, and   labor market conditions remained weak
Overall loan demand continued to decline, but at a somewhat slower rate   than in the previous survey
Since the last survey, contacts noted that   transportation activity had been flat but expected improvements over the next   three months
Commercial construction activity declined and   sales slowed resulting in lower prices
Retailers reported strong sales of cold weather   apparel and lower-priced goods but sluggish sales of jewelry and summer   merchandise
Agricultural conditions were mixed
Labor markets remained weak, but some   signs of improvement were noted
Wge increases remained modest
) indicated   that manufacturing activity increased in Minnesota and the Dakotas because of   strong new orders
Residential construction activity was slow
Retail spending was mixed
Kansas City   mentioned that overall drilling activity improved slightly, but that rig counts   were still at historically low levels
Manufactured   goods prices were flat to up slightly in Boston
Wges were flat in the San Francisco District, but increased   moderately in the Minneapolis District
Cleveland noted that commercial and industrial   lending was soft and consumer lending was flat or reduced
Boston reported that manufacturing   activity was mixed, but had stabilized or shown modest improvement in certain   industries
Residential construction activity remained weak in most Districts
The "cash-for-clunkers" program ended in August, leaving depleted inventories   and slower sales in its wake
Commercial real estate markets--in both the office and industrial   categories--have been steady to moderately weaker since the last report
Respondents report widespread decreases in average deposit rates

Both manufacturers and other   firms report moderate increases in prices paid but little or no change in   selling prices; looking to the months ahead, though, non-manufacturers   anticipate modest increases in prices received
The inventory of listings declined modestly, but the average number of days on   the market continued to climb
Consumer confidence measures, while still low, have risen moderately since   the last report
Retailers are generally cautious
Retailers   continued to indicate that their cost of goods has been about steady, and they   have generally kept their selling prices steady
Bankers generally expect demand for   credit to remain weak due to businesses' and consumers' lack of confidence that   economic conditions will improve significantly in the near future

"
Third District manufacturers expect further improvement in business   conditions, on balance
However, they expect   improvement to be slow
Consequently, they expect sales to be slow through the rest of the year
The corn harvest in Virginia was   nearing completion with yields described as good to excellent
Reports of wage and price changes among sectors   indicated little change, although manufacturing and retail price growth slowed   slightly
In contrast, several contacts reported somewhat weaker   demand for workers
Lending demand around the Fifth District was   mixed since our last report, although banks reported modest signs of   improvement
Contacts reported that both raw materials and finished goods prices   increased at a slower pace than in our last report
In contrast, Realtors in North Carolina reported slow housing markets,   due partly to people taking their time to look and others being cautious because   of their credit status
The   rate of retail price increases slowed slightly, while the pace of wage increases   edged up

Sales held largely steady for   most types of agricultural products, and favorable production conditions,   including ample availability of inputs, reportedly have led to excess supply for   some crops and dairy products
Contacts from the   banking industry and other industries reported stable or slightly increased loan   demand and improved credit access
Contacts generally characterized wages as flat, although some businesses   faced significant increases in the costs of employee benefits
However, on net bankers and other contacts noted   improved access to financial capital in recent months
Food manufacturers also reported   strong demand and significant sales gains
Reports suggested that   demand for housing continued to improve slowly, while demand for commercial real   estate eroded further

Activity was very slow for providers of   business services such as consulting and trucking, and reduced passenger volumes   for airlines were attributed in part to ongoing declines in business travel
Recent heavy rains   throughout much of the District have slowed crop maturity and delayed harvests
Both residential and commercial real estate declined
Over this period, total deposits increased , percent
Manufacturing   continued its net decline since our previous report, with more contacts   reporting job layoffs and fewer new orders than contacts reporting new hires and   expansions
Home sales continued to   decline throughout the Eighth District
